Hi,
         If you look back a few weeks to me posts on "continuous 
speciation control" that might help you.

         I was doing things differently in that I was adding and 
killing individuals one at a time, but you can probably adjust the 
ideas to a generational approach...

         Ian


At 13:39 05/11/2005, you wrote:
>Hi all,
>
>I'm evolving an extension of Stanley & Miikulainen's robot duel domain
>in ANJI 2.01, but I'm having trouble setting the speciation threshold.
>If I set it too high, all of my 100 chromosomes will (of course) stay
>in one specie. But when I set it a bit lower, I end up with 100
>species of 1 chromosome after some 100 generations. I can't seem to
>find the golden middle. On his FAQ
>(http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html), Kenneth Stanley
>himself presents a method to automatically set the speciation
>threshold by descreasing or increasing it with, say, 0.3, whenever the
>number of species becomes more or less than a preset target amount of,
>say, 10.
>
>However, when I apply this method (with population size 100 and target
>species count 10), then after some 100 generations I end up with 20 to
>25 species and a speciation threshold of 40 and rising. Of the
>resulting species, one specie contains 50 chromosomes, 10 species
>contain 5 chromosomes or less and 10 species contain just one chromosome.
>
>Has anyone else encountered such problems before, or have some idea to
>what might be causing this? How do you keep a 'normal' amount of more
>or less equally sized species?
